awd_titl_txt: Max-Planck-Princeton Center for Plasma Physics: A Collaboration in Plasma Astrophysics
awd_abstract_narration:
Most of the visible matter in the Universe is a plasma, that is a dilute gas of ions, electrons, and neutral particles. Many fundamental and important physical processes that occur in plasmas remain poorly understood. This, in turn, limits our ability to understand diverse phenomena in space such as how stars form or how the particles flowing from the Sun affect the upper layers of the Earth's atmosphere. It also impacts our ability to engineer and operate experiments on Earth such as magnetically confined fusion devices. The Max-Panck Princeton Center for Plasma Physics (MPPC) was established as a joint venture of the Max Planck Society in Germany, Princeton University, and the Department of Energy's Princeton Plasma Physics Laboratory (PPPL) in order to forge new collaborations between Universities, the national plasma labs, and international partners in order to investigate some of the most pressing problems in plasma physics. By supporting students and early career scientists, the MPPC serves to train the next generation of experimental, computational, and theoretical plasma physicists, and its international scope provides unique training for early career scientists. The center provides unique opportunities for the public, as well as students and teachers at public and regional schools, to engage in scientific inquiry in ways that enhance their understanding of science concepts and scientific ways of thinking through a well established outreach program at PPPL.

The MPPC effort at Princeton University is focused on three cross-cutting problems in plasma astrophysics: cosmic ray transport and feedback, the interplay between turbulence and reconnection, and dynamo action in accretion disks, stellar convection, and galaxies. New fluid closure models for cosmic rays will be developed and applied to models of the interstellar medium in galaxies to understand the role of cosmic-ray feedback on galaxy formation. New theoretical and computational studies of magnetic field amplification by dynamo action driven by the magneto-rotational instability in accretion disks, and convection in rotating stars, will be undertaken. Using new computational tools developed by members of the MPPC, new studies of plasma turbulence in the kinetic regime, relevant to conditions in the solar wind, will be developed. The Center fosters interdisciplinary collaboration between the plasma and astrophysics communities, as well as international collaboration between these communities in the US, Germany, and elsewhere. Its international scope provides unique training for graduate students and postdocs.  This award provides renewed support for Princeton University's participation in MPPC, with support for PPPL's participation provided by the Department of Energy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Max Planck Princeton Center for Plasma Physics (MPPC) was a collaborative research project between Princeton University, Princeton Plasma Physics Laboratory, and several institutes of the Max Planck Society in Germany. This grant supported the Princeton branch of the MPPC and was aimed at enabling collaborative research projects between Germany and the United States in fusion and basic plasma physics, leveraging the tools and unique strengths of each member institution. 

The researchers at the center have made significant contributions in four main research areas: magnetic reconnection, plasma turbulence, energetic particles, and plasma astrophysics. Plasmas (or ionized gases) are widely prevalent in the universe and serve as carriers of magnetic fields. Plasmas can spontaneously dissipate their magnetic energy when the field polarity reverses, through the processes of reconnection. Moreover, plasmas are known to be turbulent and can generate energetic non-thermal particles such as cosmic rays through the  processes such as shocks or magnetic reconnection. The details of these processes and their observational manifestations were the focus of this center. 

One of the key strengths of the MPPC was the cross-disciplinary nature of the research. Plasmas in astrophysical environments share behaviors and properties with plasmas encountered in the laboratory fusion and in solar wind settings. Therefore, a collaboration between astrophysicists, experts in laboratory plasmas, and heliophysicists helped to share the expertise between these subdisciplines, leading to fruitful scientific collaborations.

The center supported postdoctoral fellows and graduate students, facilitated US-German postdoc exchanges, and held annual meetings that alternated between Germany and the US, with invited speakers from both inside and from outside of the collaboration.  

The main scientific outcomes of the MPPC include the development of the theory of magnetic field generation and amplification (the dynamo effect) in sheared stratified flows, with applications to the radiative zone of stars and to the shear layers at the interface of merging neutron stars. The center researchers also demonstrated the growth of small-scale instabilities (firehose and mirror) during the dynamo amplification of magnetic field in a turbulent flow, with applications to long term evolution of magnetic fields in turbulent accretion disks. In addition, the center members simulated the propagation of energetic cosmic rays through the interstellar medium, including the growth and saturation of cosmic ray-excited instabilities in different regimes of cosmic ray scattering. They also simulated the role of magnetic reconnection in accretion disks around black holes, finding that reconnection can efficiently accelerate particles in disk coronae. Furthermore, the center researchers developed simulation and theory of particle acceleration in shock waves for solar wind and supernova remnant parameters, demonstrating how efficiency of particle acceleration depends on the speed and magnetic field of an astrophysical shock wave.

In addition to scientific outcomes, MPPC has contributed to the development of advanced open source computer simulation technology to improve the fidelity of plasma simulations using particles- and fluid-based techniques. The work done in the center became an important part of four PhD theses at Princeton. The center members published over 80 papers, presented at dozens of conferences, supervised summer undergrad projects and taught at several successful summer schools for undergraduate and early graduate students.
